(upbeat music) - Matt, welcome to the
"AWS for Data" show.
- Thanks, Sandy. - So you are the senior vice president of linguistic AI at RWS.

Let's break that up bit. Can you please explain to our
viewers what is linguistic AI and what do you do as
the senior vice president

at RWS?
- Yeah, brilliant. Well, thanks for having
me here today, Sandy.

Linguistic AI is a portfolio
of products that covers
quite a large gamut of use cases. So we have, on the one end, B2B offerings,

this is a suite called Trados, and this we sell to
enterprises and governments

to help manage huge, huge
localization translation projects.
As part of that, we have another offering called Language Weaver. And this is a,

well, it's a neural machine
translation platform, and a neural machine translation platform

is something that we
built eight years ago. So this is, feels odd to say, but this is a legacy or traditional AI,

it's not generative AI, and this is about machine translating, automated translation of
vast amounts of content.
And thirdly, we have our B2C offering, which is called Trados Studio.

And this is a platform
where linguists, translators can spend their day and be
effective and productive

as a translator. So what do I do? I'm head
of this product portfolio.

So I look after the product management and the RnD for taking all of these
products to market.

- Thank you. I mean, we had some interaction
before this podcast, and language translation business
sounds really interesting to me. There's so many interesting use cases that you are working on at RWS,

and we'll dive into some of them today.
- Indeed, there are. Yeah.
- Yeah. Steven, thank you very much
for joining me in this show.

You and I worked closely with our software and SaaS
businesses in the UK and Ireland. For our viewers, can
you explain what you do

as an AI/ML specialist? - Well, thank you. Thank
you, Sandy, for having me. My name's Steven.

I'm part of the specialist
organizations in AWS. Essentially what I do is we help enterprise software companies

to help them to grow their business with our AI solutions and
services across the stack.

Essentially, you could think of me as, we ran a team of
individuals, of specialists that helps to every level
of our organizations,
from ideation to experimentation. So even building best practices, you know, when a customer's going to production.

So one thing very unique
about what my role is, is we get a chance to build,

not just about AI use cases
for internal's consumption, but also how do we embed
these AI capabilities

as part of the product software
that's customer facing. So that's a bit of unique
about what I do within AWS.

- Nice. I'm pretty sure you've
been very busy recently with generative AI. - Yes, quite a bit. (laughs)
- Okay. Matt, so if I build an online course,
and I build it in English, and I wanted to reach out to audiences that speak other languages,
would your product be helpful in terms of translating my online course into other languages?

- Absolutely. So you're gonna be thinking, "I need to reach more audience," and your example there
is an online learning,

so this is potentially
some post-sale content, but equally, it might be your website,

it might be your marketing material, it could be your user guides,
your community forums.

It could be your data labels for your latest drug, etc. There's a huge range of
different types of content
which would all need different outcomes. So if we look to your training there,
you have three things on your mind, how do I optimize the cost, how do I optimize the turnaround time

and the quality? And that's what we're doing
every day of the week, it's bringing the right technology

and the right service level in order to give you the right
output for your training,

which will be different from what you need for your
marketing or your community. You know, there'll be a different balance

of human and machine. So that's what we do, we look to provide the full spectrum of services
and tech-enabled services
and tech-only to meet all of the needs of our customers and their content.

- This is really interesting because when I was thinking
about this example, right, I was just thinking about
translating the course,

but what you have said is
there's a full spectrum, like, how do I market
it to those audiences? That's a different kind of translation

that you would need to do. And then, you know, there
might be post sales, so how I market, how
I deliver the content,
how I collect feedback. So there's a whole journey where the translation will be required not only at the core course level.

And that's what you cover for every businesses in
other industries that needs these kind of services.
- Absolutely.

And for all of the effort that you put into
creating the right course, that can be undone by not
translating into a local language
where your audience can properly engage with the content that you've created.

- So interesting. It is quite evident now that generative AI is
transforming organizations
in every sector, and I'm pretty sure it's happening in your organization as well.

Can you give us some examples or just explain what is
changing in your organization and how generative AI is
bringing those changes?
- Generative AI is providing, it's a massive step change.

We were talking earlier
about how, you know, the localization and the
data industry has been
pretty flat in terms of innovation. Gen AI, as such a universal tool,

it means that it's got a
use case for everybody, use case for data, use
case for linguistics, use case for a million
other types of business.
But I think what they all have in common in the early days of generative AI is that the focus tends to be on

how do we save some costs. And that's the easiest way to approach it because you can still
bring the human in to that.

And that's how I think the best
use cases are really showing

the most value at the moment. One example from our point of view, we recently released a
capability called Evolve,

and what that does is it pieces together a lot of our existing
and new technologies. So what it does is, for your,

let's say, your training
course that you've got here, it would run neural machine translation

to translate everything with the machine. Then the first clever thing
it does is it uses an LLM

to go and figure out which of those machine
translation sentences is good and which is poor.

Now, the good ones, that's
where we get a cost saving because that doesn't need to
see another human potentially.

And then what was not good,
that can go to a second LLM, and we see if we can
improve it using that LLM.
So we're minimizing the amount of work which a human needs to get involved with. Now, that's great because, number one,

you know, as I said, good
use cases at the moment are about reducing cost, but also, we keep that fail-safe

of having a human in
the loop to guide this. And we see AI here as
being a digital colleague,
just somebody with their own skills that's come into the team, and we use that for scaling

and for that sort of work, whereas the creativity
still sits with the human. So that's where we are today,

and that's where I see all
the really good use cases. In the future, I think
that we move to something which is much more about
generating content.
So when you're generating content, we can be approaching use cases where we're looking to drive revenue,
not just reducing costs. So for your training course, if you could talk to me in my language

and you could talk to
me as my demographic, you could talk to me knowing
something about me personally,

that's gonna make me
engaged that much more to purchase your training, and then, after the sale,
to stay loyal and engaged with you. So I think that's maybe the nuance change

that I could see in the next year or so, moving from, you know, pure
cost saving and moving towards

some revenue-generating use cases as well. - This is so incredible. So what you're saying is
with content generation side,

and taking the example
of my online course, if I wanted to do an online course on generative AI, for example,

experts, to professionals,

to elders, right, then
I can actually create, use the same course to
create different content

engaging your different
audiences if you changed those and made them more culturally appropriate?
- This is going to be so interesting for content creators as well, right? - Absolutely.

- I think this is a
communication business, right? So you're in the language business.
How do you see generative AI evolving the social communication

and social constructs
around communication? - I think the change is gonna be huge.

And the first is, you know, I mentioned our Evolve capability, now, that's all about
getting more content through.

It's not about necessarily
reducing the cost, it's about reducing unit cost
so you can translate more,

which means that more
of the global audience will be able to engage with

in their language. Now, engaging with me in my language boosts my likelihood to convert,

it makes me feel much
more loyal to your brand, I'll stay around, I'll
be supported better,

so more individuals globally will be better linked to
your brand with better,
more localized content. I think that's the biggest change even before we start thinking about, well, we could generate content in order

to be more applicable to
you or to your demographic or your culture. That's all great stuff. But I think immediately,

and this is, you know, we only
released Evolve a month ago, and already we've got great benefits

with some key customers. That really show that the
customers we're talking to don't necessarily want to save the cost,

they want to drive more content and get more engagement from
their growing global audience.

- Amazing, amazing. I mean, I'm so interested
in your business now and how it's going to
change social communication,

thinking from different
perspectives, businesses, content creators, you know,
we watch YouTube videos,

we make a lot of content
through AWS like this one and how language translation services

can really revolutionize this whole space is really-
- One thing I'd add, Sandy,

if you don't mind, is this is a really good example of how different content
types need different outcomes.

So this video we do here isn't necessarily going
to need the same treatment as a glossy

AWS advert or something
you're gonna put on the screen at the summit tomorrow, right?

These all have different outputs and different amounts of
investment you want to make. So having the spectrum of
services and technology

so that you get the right outcome with the right cost, time and

- Fantastic. So, Steve, you spend most
of your time with customers

working on, nowadays,
generative AI use cases. What are the major trends that you observe

in customers who are able to
successfully implement them in production?
- Yeah, right. Well, thank you for the questions. So, well, primarily, I think there are

three buckets I see specifically around
enterprise software companies. Well, first off is our
most low-hanging fruit,

the whole optimization, the
internal efficiency aspect, which is, you know,
there's a lot of use cases around documentation.

How do you achieve, you
know, a lot of the insights within your organizations more quickly or even language
translation for that matter?
So that's the first bucket. And the second piece is really around the product innovation, right,
in a way that is how do you start using these gen AI or LLM models

to make your software to be
a lot more user-friendly, a lot more personalized? So when I say personalized,

not necessarily just
about humanized chat bot, what I'm referring to is
that organizations actually
building this layer of interactions, where, traditionally, let's say, you need a technical audience

or you need a specific domain
to exercise on the software. Now they could actually use
this much more natural language way for them to interact with the software. So what that really means,

from a benefits perspective
for software companies is it's actually creating new stickiness,

it's actually creating a
new demographic of audience where they could start
using this software.

So that's the second
bucket that we're seeing in terms of product innovation. And then lastly, I think,

it's a really hot topic right now is about democratizing insight. When I say, when I say
democratizing insight,

it's not necessarily just, hey, you have data just sitting
somewhere within the cloud you couldn't access to,
but it's also about how to extrapolate domain insights from humans, from, you know, humans' mind.
Because one of the things that we start working very closely with across different organization is they want to begin to start building

this internal intelligence
search type of capability where you can have different
department from finance, HR,
they all want to have their own model that could effectively help them to do their job much quicker.

So throughout that
process is, essentially, you have to have that domain knowledge

from a finance person, from a HR person, so then you could start
training up this model. So the other aspect I
definitely start seeing

is also democratizing. So you're not introducing
a single point of failure and also building longevity
for the organizations
in terms of the domain knowledge that stays in the organization. So at least those are the three buckets

that I consistently see as
an overall theme right now. - Right.
- We have a natty little way

of describing that, Steven. So we talk about artificial intelligence
and human intelligence

becoming genuine intelligence.
- Yes. - And that's about,
yeah, I mentioned before, bringing that digital
colleague into your team

but treating them as you would anyone with their own, you know,
strengths and weaknesses. But just the technology on its own,
which misses out all of that creativity and the subject matter expertise,

is a real mistake.
- Yeah. Exactly.
- Genuine intelligence, did you say?
- Genuine intelligence.

- Genuine intelligence.
- That's a nice term. It's the first time I've
heard about it, but yeah. Just to uncover on your,
so you said that bringing domain knowledge from different departments, right, and putting my
data architect hat on, what I'm thinking is that translates into bringing data from different departments,

you know, creating this
unified view of data. And that means you would either

create pipelines that bring
data from different parts, and what that means is that
you need to do some sort of,

you know, you have to
build some sort of platform that modernizes the way you handle data,

make sure that data is of quality. Is that what you're observing
organizations doing?

- Yeah, absolutely. I think it's, one of the things I'm seeing a lot is, especially last year, a lot
of experimentation, including

RWS's, but now we're start talking about how do you blueprint your production? So if you start thinking
about this capability,

you really wanna take it at scale. It doesn't matter your
enterprise software or not, you have to make sure that
you have the right data

to feed into this model, right? Because you want the most accurate data to continues to get the
most accuracy of this model.

So in a way that, I begin to start seeing a lot of customers that, hey,
yes, now we have a proven case

of a gen AI capabilities, and they begin to start
really looking into, what we call it, the
working-backward process

of looking into, hey, do I have the right
data infrastructure to support this capability,

which could potentially,
you know, drive revenue and optimizations internally, so. - I think that the fascinating
thing about gen AI,

which is different to any other innovation that I've been been a part of, is that the technology
itself is pretty repeatable.

It's all on the cloud,
thank you very much, you know, all of the LLMs are, you know,
publicly available, and you can prompt it. So any engineer or anybody who can type

can get an output from this. But what that does mean is that that technology can, to a
certain extent, be repeated.

And there's two things
which are the uniqueness, it's finding the value so that
the use case you are driving

is actually going to be
worth something in the end to your customers, and the data. So the data which isn't
in the foundational model,

that's the moat, that's the secret sauce that we're all adding
to our own, you know,

offerings that we're taking to market. - And this is why we say your
data is your differentiator, right?
- Yep. There you go.

- And your oil.
- Yeah, yeah. Talking about data and talking about data
being your differentiator,

how do you make sure that
the data is of high quality? Because, ultimately, you're
going to train your models on that high quality data.

What are the steps that you take to ensure you are training your
models on high quality data?

- Yeah. So the first thing I would say is that we're not in the business as
the vast majority, I would say,

of people watching this
and people in industry, we're not in the business
of building LLMs.

The amount of investment that
it takes is mind-boggling, and there's plenty available out there.

So what we're not doing is building those, but what we are doing is very
carefully choosing the LLM

or the LLMs, plural,
that we are going to use. So we

look at the LLMs predominantly in Bedrock, that's where we look first, and we're looking at, you know, how those providers
are sourcing their data
like bias or hate or misinformation, all that sort of stuff.

And we're looking to make sure
that we make the right choice at that foundational level because anything that
you do on top of that
is a waste of time if you haven't got the right foundational model. So that's our first thing that we do. And the second is,

once we have that and we
establish what the guardrails are and where the data came
from for the training

from the provider of the LLM, then we look to our engineers, and we provide training and
guidance for our engineers

to be doing a belt and
braces approach, right? So we're assuming that the
input and the output of the LLM
is going to be, for want of a better word, clean, unbiased,

you know, no hate speech
and no inaccuracies, but in reality, you know,
of course there will be.

So the rest of that we
clean up in clever prompting to make sure that we are removing those

as outputs as well as
the input to the LLMs. - So that raises another
question in my mind.

You're talking about
content that might not be preferable to every audience, right?

And in that scenario, and considering that
your services reach out

to different regions, different
customers and audiences,

you know, speaking different languages, how do you address ethical
concerns with data privacy
and, you know, regional context?

Some regions might prefer
some sort of content compared to other regions, right?
- Yeah. We look at it as a pyramid of data.

So you have your foundational at the base, and then you might have
some training that we do
to enhance the foundational model, which might be for an industry, okay? Then you might then have something

which is for a horizontal use case, and then at the top,
you might have something which is specifically for that customer.

So we look, as we then train
on that foundational model, we look to make sure that we're
using the data that we have

in the right place. So if it's just industry terminology that's going to be open to
all users in the automotive

or in the pharma industries,
then we'll build that, and now suddenly we've got a model which accounts for a certain industry.
But if it's something that we're taking from a customer specifically, then we make sure that we only output that
for that particular customer as well. So we do that in a few ways. The first thing is that we try to minimize
the amount of fine tuning. And the reason for that is that

we have lots of different
requirements for LLMs, and we're certain that
we are not going to, even in the future, have one LLM

which meets all of our needs. So our particular need is
about multilingual knowledge,
so where the foundational data came from and what languages were included. So we know, in the future,

as more LLMs pick up more
and more long-tail languages
that we'll be, we'll need to add more LLMs to our stack, which means that if we fine tune one,

we've got to fine tune the rest. And that, you know,
becomes a big investment. So we really try to limit our
training to two main things. One is we use

synthetic data and our own
teams to do annotation. So if you think about that
quality estimation component

of the Evolve capability
I talked about before, that's all about
synthesizing a human decision

to allow a machine to say
whether that machine translation was good or not. So what we do is we generate

tens of thousands of machine translations and we give it to our linguists to annotate as either
being good or not good.

I'm gonna work on it or I'm
not gonna need to work on it. And so that data is universal,
we can use, that's our data,

it's synthetic and it's our
own resources annotating it, so we'll use that for everybody.
But we also have a layer which is we use retrieval augmented generation,

which means if I'm working for
you on your training content, everything I've done for you previously, we have a database of all
of those translations.

We've also agreed with you what terminology is in your training and how you'd like that
translating in different languages,

which means that for you,
when we do our prompts, we would look for

examples of good translations
from that database. We'd look for allowable terminology,

we'll include that in the prompt so we get a much more
specific and accurate
translation and decision from the AI than we would from our general model.
You would have, as another customer, a different set of translation memories, that database and terminology.

And so we'd use the right
one at the right time. So data is hugely important
to us and to our customers,

and we are absolutely committed to make sure that by
adding new innovation,

we're not poking a hole in how we've been able to
control data previously.

- Yeah. Sounds like you're not
just leveraging LLMs, it's, like, the whole pipeline

to make this whole thing work, right?
- That's right. - From the vector
database, RAG and so forth. - Yeah.
- Got it.

- It's about choosing the right technology at the right time. If we just threw everything
at LLM, we'd get a result. It would be a worse result,

and it would've cost
us a fortune to create, so, you know-
- Makes sense. - lose loose. - What is fascinating to me

is you are using machines
to generate data,

like, generate translation
of original content, and then you're using
linguists, who are humans,

to check that content, okay some of that, and then you use that as
a feed to your models,
and then they generate another set of data which are of higher quality, and that's how you ensure

data quality.
- Absolutely. If you think about our data
flow and our process flow, which goes through the
entire supply chain,

so we have a privileged access to every single touch point
in this whole transaction, the number of loops that
we're now building in

is incredible. And that's something we're
really striving to do to make sure that none of the data
goes to waste, you know?

That are uses for all of this data, we need to find them.
- Makes sense. - And the retrieval
augmented generation pattern
that you talked about is basically, what you're saying is that taking my online course as an example,

if I create a really
highly-technical online content as a course, like configuring
security for something

which go a deep technical level. So explaining how to

for a particular service on AWS and translating it from
English to other languages,

then you can use this contextual data stored somewhere in the database to meet that level of depth
in the technical accuracy.

then you'll have firewall, let's say. And for this particular bit of content, your terminology would make sure

that probably you wouldn't translate that, if we went into French and German, I'm not a linguist myself, so I've got no idea what
firewall is in French and German,

but let's imagine it's
just firewall, right? Whereas if we were doing this for your construction

we're gonna need to translate that as the wall's on fire, you know? So yeah, definitely context

for the outputs. - So your business has

of a translation service
business like yours, how do you ensure inclusivity

one for me personally.
We're a leader in what we do, and so I think we have a responsibility to make sure that we do that.

In my grander moments, I think this is, this is, you know, leave no
translator behind, right?

This is something that
needs to be universal, and that's something we
look at all the time.

But the approach that I take is that because everything is in the cloud for us, natively in the cloud, it
means that once we build it,

in order to make it inclusive, it's just how we then take that to market, how we take that to
users, how we deploy it.

But all of the smarts, all of the integration of
gen AI or whatever it is is done in the cloud.
And then the challenge is just getting it to the individuals at the end, so.

For example, we spend a lot of time building a hybrid model
for translators similar to
Office, where you can work online or you can work on your desktop. Now, that's great for a preference,

but it's really powerful
for if you are in a region which has unstable communications
or unpredictable power,

so the ability to choose
whether I'm gonna work locally, completely offline, or I'm gonna go online,

they're not just a
preference, that's necessity. We also think about, I've
talked about, you know,

the next billion internet users are gonna be speaking a different language
to the first billion.

Now, that means that
there aren't necessarily big communities of those translators, professional translators
with our technology

waiting to jump. So we need to look down
the line and think, "Okay,

customers who want to go global truly and pick up the next
billion internet users are gonna need completely
different languages."

So they're gonna need
completely different, completely new community of linguists, and we're gonna need a

based on the same cloud. We all have the same features, but we just surface it to

that makes sense for them because they haven't necessarily been to university for four years to learn how to use our desktop tools.

We need to provide something much more simple and approachable for people who are just
picking up translation

because they're bilingual, and the, you know, globalizing
companies need to engage

with users, their
customers in that language. So it's quite complicated,

how to bring people in,

new communities of users as
we go to make it inclusive. - Yeah, that's actually

the steps that you're taking

around, you know,

an audience. So I'm just curious, what

who are going global

- Yeah. That's a great question.

Well, ultimately, I think yes, you have to establish the right culture, and also the data literacy is
pretty much the foundations

of implementing any type of AI solutions. But one thing for sure is
it's not a one-day thing,

it's a journey of itself. But fundamentally, I think there's three
typical areas that I'm seeing

that we usually start
off those conversations. One is obviously around the
whole data-driven culture.

A lot of organizations,
especially in the past decade, this is not just an AI thing, right, everybody, hey, we
gotta make our decisions
much more data driven, but in reality, what has happened, what I've seen in a lot of organization are we just building more reports,

like more, more, more, more, more SQL reports to help customers? But in reality, I think what customers

actually embedding these type
of specific data capabilities into part of the business process.
